author: Human1229
title: Its a Blue-and-Orange-Jay
review:
Played by Kumail Nanjiani in the movie, a Pakistani-American stand-up comedian, Jay the blue ninja is one of the main characters who also happens to be a ninja. I picked him up at the Lego Store today. Lets see how good a figure he is.

 

Parts:

Jay Walker is consisted of nine pieces, including his accesories. But let's not ignore the elephant in the room - the selfie stick. Though selfies were never my thing, I think it is interesting that Lego chose to make a selfie stick for not one - but two sets. (The other is the Harley Quinn Dorm Room for DC Superhero Girls.) This selfie stick is made of four pieces, including the phone. He also has a new scarf piece, my favorite part of the set, and a new hair piece. Underneath the scarf is a button-up jacket covering up a white polo shirt only visible without the scarf. 

 

The figure:

Jay has lightning patterns on his jacket, probably because he's the lightning ninja, and freckles on his grinning face. He is squinting, perhaps for the picture. He wears khaki pants and has a new curly hairdo in dark brown. His orange scarf wraps around his neck perfectly, but there is no printing on the back of his torso. His printed-on pant pockets are a nice touch. The phone has his face on it, as well as various buttons. There is a city skyline behind his face on the phone.

To feel for him, feel for a rod and then a couple more small pieces, then comfirm with a 1x2 tile.

 

Conclusion:

Jay is one of my favorite minifigures in this series.

author: LEGODUDE1
title: NINJA-GO!
review:
This is an odd choice for a review, but I wanted to try something odd.

Here goes.

This minifigure is Jay Walker, AKA the Blue Ninja. He is one of 20 minifigures from the LEGO Ninjago Movie Collectible Minifigures theme. This minifigure includes a unique orange scarf piece and a hair piece similar to a version of Han Solo's. 

Jay is holding a phone on a stand and taking a picture of himself.

This review isn't very good.

Reviews on minifigures are hard.

END

author: Odeinoichus
title: Seriously, what a pun-tastic name.
review:
Set #71019 Jay Walker: We now return to the reviewing of The LEGO Ninjago Movie CMF series with Jay in his civilian clothing. I never noticed before that his last name was Walker, which, when you think about it, makes for a very punny name for the Ninja of Lightning.

His print is relatively simple, with single-sided torso printing, minor printing for the pockets and a single-sided face. Along with his stunning new hair piece he looks very nice, factor in the inclusion of a brand new scarf piece to wear around the neck indicates that LEGO is really expanding on the Minifigure accessories. Speaking of which, a nice buildable selfie-stick with a printed tile for a cell phone round out the figure quite nicely and looks great.

Overall I'd definitely recommend this figure, he's got a lot of nice re-useable parts for MOCing characters, and he represents, very faithfully, the civilian clothes of Jay Walker.
